description: Erection of part single, part two-storey side extension and single storey rear extension (following demolition of existing garage and conservatory)
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the submitted application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows at first floor level in the east elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level in the east elevation of the dwelling house currently known as "17 Kings Avenue, New Malden, KT3 4DU" as set out in Section 1 (Site Address) of the submitted application form signed 24.02.2021, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling located within the 2.8 Old Malden Area of Archaeological Significance.The application is located within the Critical Drainage Area. Proposal Erection of two storey side, first floor side and rear extension.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. 1 neutral representation has been received with comments summarised as follows:- Concerns regarding the drainage as the proposal would significantly increase the footprint/roof area; Possible adverse impact on soakways and drainage at the adjoining property. Officer comment: Whilst the application site falls within the critical drainage area, given the scale of the proposal and the proposed footprint, it is not considered to adversely affect the existing drainage systems or result in increased surface water flooding. In any event the use of a Soakaway on neighbouring land would be a matter for the neighbours to agree between themselves. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Manor Close was originally characterised by semi-detached dwellings with cat-slide roofs. However, over recent years the character of the street scene has changed. A number of properties have been extended by means of first floor side extensions which has resulted in the loss of the original cat-slide roof at No 12 (ref: 19/03082/HOU), at No. 3 (ref: 16/14130/HOU), No. 6 (ref: 12/14210/HOU) and No.8 (ref: 27806). These constructed first floor side extensions have not been set-back from the front elevation and contain a hipped roof form.In this case, the proposed first floor side extension would be of a similar design to those constructed on the adjoining properties nos 8 and 10. The proposed two storey side extension, due to its modest width and siting and the proposed roof form would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and similar developments on Manor Close. The proposed first floor rear extension would be approximately 2.4m deep. Given its siting and the proposed scale as well as the proposed roof design it is considered to be acceptable. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The proposed extension would pass the 45 and 25 degree rules in relation to the nearest habitable windows at both adjoining properties. Given the proposed scale and siting of the extension, it is not considered to appear as an overbearing when viewed from the adjoining properties. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Compliance with Policy D12(A) - 10 Manor Close statement, which is considered to be acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises commercial premises on Church in the mixed in use area. The site is located in Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and the host property is a listed building.Consultation Heritage Officer - no objection to the revision subject to conditions.Kingston Town CAAC - Objection. Positives of this PA include the improved shop frontage & new cast iron rain water goods throughout. But these are more than offset by the following negatives which would cause harm to the character & appearance of 12/12/2024, 10:29 KTCAAC. this grade 2 listed building & wider CA: acrylic moulded logos on front, side & rear elevations in contravention of the LPA's guidelines on development in CAs (comments on 24/02411 refer); bladed/ projecting signs at first floor level & illuminated on the front & part side elevations, again in breach of the Council's guidance (see 24/02411); new plant, including unspecified solar panels, on rear/ side roof top which would be clearly visible from the public realm; installation of a door to first floor canteen onto rear roof space,resulting in an inappropriate outdoor amenity in this location. The magazine hopper cut into shop front would be the first of its kind in the market place and would need to be executed with care.Relevant History 24/02411/ADV - Display of 3nos internally illuminated fascia signs and 1no externally illuminated projecting sign. - Granted on 21.03.2025 24/02380/LBC - Fenestration alteration, installation of ventilation grilles. Replacement of rainwater goods with cast iron. Roof work with new slate tiles in existing pitched roof, new deck on rear top flat roof and first floor flat roof including roof covering. Brickwork repairment. Internal alteration and advert. pendingProposal Fenestration alteration, installation of ventilation grilles. Replacement of rainwater goods with cast iron. Roof work with new slate tiles in existing pitched roof, new deck on rear top flat roof and first floor flat roof including roof covering. Brickwork repairment. Internal alteration and advert.AssessmentDesign and Heritage Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas and listed buildings, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  The NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal would include fenestration alteration, installation of ventilation grilles, replacement of rainwater goods with cast iron, roof work with new slate tiles in existing pitched roof, new deck on rear top flat roof and first floor flat roof including roof covering, brickwork repairment, internal alteration and advertisement for signs and logo.The applicant removed the solar panel element during the course of the application. Council's Heritage Officer was consulted and no objection was raised subject to a pre-commencement condition for submission and approval of windows, doors and louvre vents details.It is considered that the proposed works would preserve the building's appearance and special architectural features and its historic interest.It is considered that the proposal would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property or the surrounding area or harm the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and the listed building.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Given its scale, design and location, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.FloodThe site is located in Environment Agency Flood Zone 2, however no ground works are proposed and the site footprint will not alter. Therefore it is considered not to have a significant impact on this element. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Reasonable Exemption Statement. The submitted information is considered appropriate and this element will not be adversely affected by the development. Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.

Please provide a Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline. The Block Plan does not show a hatched area for the location of the charger.

Please provide all Existing and Proposed Elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work. A scale bar is encouraged.Your Elevations do not meet the above requirements.No Existing Elevations have been submitted.Please provide all Proposed Elevations where the charger will be seen, and please state the scale.
